page.title: 01Strath Carnaig, E Sutherland
page.content: The Carnaig River flows steeply down from W to E with hill & rough moorland on each side. It is thickly wooded in places beside the river, especially on the S bank, with natural birch and alder. The Farm of Torboll is N of the river & the crofting township of Little Torboll (now 2 inhabited houses) to the S below a steep hill, Creag an Amalaidh, overlooking the head of Loch Fleet. In the NE the hills fall away sharply from 500ft to sea level, into Strath Fleet, once a tidal estuary, now thickly wooded marsh, "The Alders", where Ospreys nest. The Carnaig winds across to join the Fleet above its mouth. The rest is rough, bleak moorland with no habitation other than at the Torboll settlements, but it abounds in hut circles and cairns, evidence of former people here.
